Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant met the residence requirement under the Citizenship Act
Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; matter remitted for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about applicant's compliance due to inconsistent evidence
Legal_Provision: Requirement of at least three years of residence in Canada within four years before application
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged failure to meet residence requirement
Application_Error: Failure to clearly apply test for residence (intention or physical presence)
Decision_Outcome: Remanded to another citizenship judge for reassessment

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 5(1) of the Citizenship Act - Residency requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present in Canada for 1,081 days within the four-year period preceding the application, which is 14 days short of the required 1,095 days
Residency_Compliance: Insufficient physical presence; 1,081 days out of 1,095 required
Procedural_Issue: Applicant argued that the 'centralization of life' test should apply instead of the physical presence test
Evidence_Used: Record of entry and exit dates, travel history, supporting documents for time spent in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient documentation to prove additional days of residence; failure to demonstrate exceptional circumstances warranting alternative assessment
Outcome: Appeal dismissed by Federal Court
Relief_Sought: Overturning of citizenship judge's decision and approval of citizenship application
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the citizenship judge’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test under the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The citizenship judge correctly applied the statutory physical presence requirement; 'centralization of life' test does not apply absent exceptional circumstances
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission, Federal Court on appeal

Legal_Issue: Did the Citizenship Judge provide adequate reasons for approving the Respondent's application and did they err in finding that residency requirements were met?
Outcome: Appeal granted, case sent back for reassessment by a different Citizenship Judge
Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about discrepancies in employment history affecting credibility
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged failure to meet residency requirements and inadequate reasoning by the judge
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Adequacy of reasons provided by the Citizenship Judge
Application_Error: Failure to clearly apply residency tests and justify acceptance of evidence
Evidence_Ignored: Potential gaps or inconsistencies in employment history relevant to residency
Legal_Standard: Clear, precise, and intelligible reasons required under subsection 14(2)

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present in Canada for only 173 days, falling short of the required 1,095 days; lived and worked in Mexico
Procedural_Issue: Appeal filed under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Used: Record of physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient days of physical presence documented
Outcome: Applicant remains ineligible for citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada as established in Re Pourghasemi
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge correctly applied the residency requirement and provided adequate reasons; applicant failed to meet physical presence requirement

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present for 691 days; maintained strong ties to Canada including family, property, and frequent returns
Residency_Compliance: No – fell short of 1,095-day requirement; central mode of existence disputed
Procedural_Issue: Misapplication of the Re Koo centralized mode of existence test; factual errors by Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, family ties, property ownership, travel history
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient assessment of comparative ties to Canada vs. other countries
Outcome: Case remanded to another Citizenship Judge for re-determination
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of residency based on proper application of law and facts
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralized mode of existence test from Re Koo
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for factual and legal issues; correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Significant factual errors and misapplication of the Re Koo test in assessing residency
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Judge, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present for only 117 days in the four years preceding the application, falling short by 978 days of the required 1,095 days
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet minimum physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under s. 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Used: Record of absences and presence over four-year period
Outcome: Applicant remains ineligible for citizenship
Decision_Rationale: Statutory interpretation requires literal physical presence; qualitative approach not applicable

Legal_Issue: Adequacy of reasons provided by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for re-assessment
Legal_Provision: Residency requirement of 1095 days under the Citizenship Act
Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient physical presence in Canada (265 days short)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to meet residency requirement, inadequate judicial reasoning
Application_Error: Approval despite failure to meet statutory residency requirement
Assessment_Standard: Clear and detailed reasons required for approval
Legal_Standard: Reasons must be clear, transparent, and justified under law
Application_Factor: Duration of physical presence in Canada

Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge's decision adequately explained how the residence requirement was met
Evidence_Assessment: Contradictions in evidence regarding residency were not addressed
Decision_Outcome: Original decision set aside due to inadequate reasoning
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compliance with residence requirements
Legal_Rule: Standard of review for adequacy of reasons is correctness; determination of residence compliance is reviewed under reasonableness standard
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for adequacy of reasons; reasonableness for residence determination
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient reasoning by citizenship judge, failure to apply clear residency test
Outcome_on_Merits: Decision referred to another judge for redetermination
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's continued residence in France since 2005 while holding permanent resident status in Canada
Legal_Framework: Canadian Citizenship Act, residency requirements for naturalization
Defendant_Response: Baron did not appear or defend the application
Evidence_Type: Residency records, application documents, judicial findings
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review sought by the Crown
Outcome: Original decision annulled, case remanded for reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Residence requirement under Canadian citizenship law

Application_Facts: Appellant accumulated only 357 days of residence in Canada during the four years preceding the application while studying abroad
Residency_Compliance: No, failed to accumulate 1,095 days of physical presence
Procedural_Issue: Appeal reviewed and dismissed by Federal Court Trial Division
Evidence_Used: Record of days physically present in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of required residency duration
Outcome: Citizenship application denied
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of residence within four years prior to application under Section 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Appellant did not meet statutory residency requirement due to prolonged absence from Canada for studies

Application_Facts: Saad's citizenship application was approved by a citizenship judge; the Minister appealed, arguing inadequate reasoning.
Residency_Compliance: The judge did not specify which residence test was used or why it was met.
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate reasons provided by the citizenship judge, leading to an unclear and unintelligible decision.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to clarify the basis for meeting the residence requirement.
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application initially approved by judge.
Outcome: Appeal allowed; decision set aside and remitted for redetermination.
Relief_Sought: Minister sought to overturn the approval of Saad's citizenship application.
Decision_Rationale: Reasons were inadequate because they failed to justify or explain which residence test was applied and how it was satisfied.

Application_Facts: Applicant Shing Timothy Wong had an extensive travel history raising doubts about physical presence in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Unclear; judge failed to assess properly
Procedural_Issue: Sparse reasons provided by citizenship judge, lack of clarity on residency test applied
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient explanation of how evidence was weighed
Outcome: Case remitted to a different citizenship judge for reconsideration
Remedy_Sought: Reevaluation with clear and detailed reasoning
Legal_Standard_Applied: Clear and detailed reasons required under subsection 14(2)
Decision_Rationale: Judge's decision lacked sufficient detail to demonstrate proper application of residency tests

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa after deportation from the U.S. and sought protection in Canada based on alleged risks in Nigeria.

Evidence_Used: Documents alleging risk from stepmother in Nigeria
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility not questioned; issue was sufficiency of evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent Residence via PRRA and H&C grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence to establish personalized risk or humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Officer found insufficient evidence of ongoing or targeted risk
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Alleged familial conflict and potential harm
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Not discredited, but low probative value

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial Review
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in immigration decision-making, including delay and assessment of marriage genuineness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR) s.4
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed, decision set aside, case remitted for reconsideration

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Marriage relationship indicators (cohabitation, shared finances, child), officer's notes and memory after delay
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPR s.4 - Requirement that marriage be genuine and not for immigration purposes
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged breach of procedural fairness due to 10.5-month delay and improper assessment focus
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: 10.5-month delay impacting reliability of officer's assessment and procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to assess marriage genuineness at the time of the interview; reliance on delayed decision affecting fairness

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential lack of consideration of ongoing marital indicators during the delay period
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing of decision relative to interview and its impact on fairness
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded to a different immigration officer for reassessment

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial Review

Crimes.Application_Factor: Temporal focus of assessment (inception vs. present)

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee eligibility criteria
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections 96 and 97
Governing_Law: Canadian refugee law, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed racial and political persecution in Guyana; Board found crimes were economically motivated, not linked to race or political opinion
Residency_Compliance: N/A - claimant was outside country of origin seeking protection
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on crime patterns in Guyana, PPP's political power, police conduct
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of racial or political motivation for harm
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant did not demonstrate personalized risk or persecution based on Convention grounds
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee or person in need of protection
Remedy_Sought: Overturn of IRB decision through judicial review
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds: race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
Decision_Rationale: Persecution was economically driven; state protection available through impartial police and functioning political system
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether BTI's counterclaim discloses a reasonable cause of action against Nintendo
Evidence_Assessment: Allegations based on privileged pleadings; false statements under Section 7(a) not substantiated
Burden_of_Proof: On BTI to establish reasonable cause of action
Credibility_Factor: Estoppel and acquiescence cannot be used as a claim, only as defense
Legal_Rule: Estoppel and acquiescence are defensive doctrines; privileged pleadings cannot support unfair competition claims
Standard_of_Review: Reasonable cause of action test under Rule 221
Grounds_for_Claim: Nintendo's approval of GAME BUDDY, alleged false statements
Outcome_on_Merits: Counterclaim dismissed for lack of merit and jurisdiction
Key_Evidence_Considered: Pleadings regarding approval of GAME BUDDY, invocation of estoppel and acquiescence
Defendant_Response: Nintendo moved to strike the counterclaim
Outcome: Counterclaim dismissed, costs awarded to Nintendo
Legal_Provision: Trade-marks Act, Section 7(a); Federal Court Rules 221 and 189

Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 19(1)(a)(ii) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Principal claimant diagnosed with aortic valvular disease; potential for excessive demand on health services due to long-term medical needs
Procedural_Issue: IAD questioned medical opinion without contradictory evidence; misinterpreted 'long term' and 'short term' prognosis
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether IAD acted within its jurisdiction in assessing medical opinion
Evidentiary_Deficiency: IAD found medical opinion insufficient and vague; court found no manifest unreasonableness
Credibility_Assessment: IAD questioned reliability of Dr. Sorokin's prognosis without expert contradiction
Decision_Outcome: IAD initially allowed appeal; decision set aside on judicial review
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; IAD decision overturned
Relief_Sought: Sponsor sought allowance of appeal against medical inadmissibility determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard; whether medical opinion is manifestly unreasonable
Decision_Rationale: IAD erred by requiring undue specificity and second-guessing medical opinion without contradictory evidence

Legal_Issue: Validity of the '784 Patent based on utility and obviousness-type double patenting
Procedural_Stage: Pre-trial injunction phase seeking prohibition of regulatory approval
Evidence_Assessment: Analysis of patent claims, expert testimony, prior art
Burden_of_Proof: On Mylan to prove invalidity of the patent
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimony supporting sound prediction of utility
Legal_Rule: Utility must be demonstrated or soundly predicted at filing date; obviousness-type double patenting requires lack of novelty or ingenuity over earlier patent
Standard_of_Review: Balance of convenience and likelihood of success on merits
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of utility, obviousness-type double patenting
Outcome_on_Merits: The '784 Patent is valid and distinct from the '377 Patent
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior art disclosing tadalafil as PDE V inhibitor, expert evidence on sound prediction, absence of clinical data at filing
Legal_Framework: Canadian Patent Act and jurisprudence on utility and double patenting
Defendant_Response: Mylan sought to invalidate the '784 Patent to market generic tadalafil
Remedy_Requested: Order prohibiting Mylan from receiving regulatory approval until patent expiry
Outcome: Court granted order, prohibiting Mylan from obtaining regulatory approval until patent expiration
Legal_Provision: Relevant provisions of Canadian Patent Law regarding utility and double patenting
Authority: Canadian court with jurisdiction over patent disputes

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reviewable error in hardship assessment under section 25 IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to conduct individualized hardship analysis
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Non-compliance with removal order affects credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 25 allows H&C relief despite non-compliance
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Exceptional hardship and establishment in Canada
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration of stay, integration, family ties
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Emphasized unauthorized status and prior non-compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Residency history, community involvement, country condition reports

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed Officer failed to consider establishment, best interests of children, and procedural fairness; however, evidence showed these were considered but weighed against other factors.
Procedural_Issue: Concerns regarding procedural fairness in the assessment of humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds
Evidence_Used: Officer's assessment including consideration of establishment, best interests of children, and procedural fairness
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no reviewable error found
Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child, procedural fairness under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Officer properly considered relevant factors including establishment and best interests of children, and no reviewable error was identified in weighing those against other considerations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Willful blindness to crimes against humanity
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Article 1F of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant admitted knowledge of torture but did not participate; was a low-ranking officer who avoided involvement in abuses
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Deserted Sri Lankan Police Force in 1997
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: CRDD initially excluded based on willful blindness; Federal Court found decision unreasonable
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Admission of knowledge of torture, rank and role in police force
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence of personal participation or knowing complicity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible fear of persecution by both LTTE and government forces
Crimes.Outcome: Case referred to new panel for re-determination
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Personal and knowing participation required for exclusion under Article 1F
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mere presence or willful blindness insufficient for exclusion; no proof of active complicity

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee status due to alleged complicity
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1F of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity through membership in Sri Lankan Police Force
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, international criminal law
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Federal Court review of CRDD decision
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State protection inadequate; applicant feared persecution from both state and non-state actors
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Fear of persecution by LTTE and government forces
Crimes.Credibility: Found credible regarding desertion and fear of persecution
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1F(a) of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Persecution based on political opinion and association
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Real risk of harm due to perceived disloyalty

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding that the applicant's low back pain was not service-related
Governing_Law: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application under Federal Court Act
Evidence_Assessment: Board ignored uncontradicted evidence including medical records and Major Zaporzan's letter; dismissed post-1996 medical records without justification
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision quashed, matter remitted for reconsideration by a different panel
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish service-related injury
Credibility_Factor: Uncontradicted medical evidence and supporting letter from military officer
Legal_Rule: Board must consider all evidence favorably to the applicant and resolve doubts in their favor
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged lack of proper consideration of service-related injury evidence
Outcome_on_Merits: Court found the Board erred in its assessment
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical records, Major Zaporzan's letter, post-1996 treatment history
Legal_Framework: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act, Federal Court Act
Evidence_Type: Medical records, official correspondence, clinical documentation
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of Board decision, re-determination by new panel
Outcome: Application allowed, decision quashed, remitted for re-determination
Legal_Provision: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act provisions on favorable interpretation and doubt resolution
